segment_selection_rules: Select segments that open with a concrete analogy/metaphor mapping the topic to a universally understood domain (e.g., 'Schlafen ist wie Fußball spielen') within the first sentence.
Select segments that contain explicit, numeric prescriptions that can be screenshot/remembered (e.g., 'Vielfachen von 90 Minuten', '6,0 / 7,5 / 9,0 / 4,5 Stunden').
Select segments that include a clear 'don’t do X' contrast immediately after the rule (e.g., 'nicht 7,0 oder 8,0'), creating a binary decision for the viewer.
Select segments that explain a single causal mechanism in one chain: action → trigger → consequence (e.g., 'Wecker reißt… mitten im Zyklus' → 'Schlaftrunkenheit').
Select segments that name the phenomenon with a label (e.g., 'Schlaftrunkenheit') to increase perceived authority and memorability.
Select segments that include a vivid sensory/emotional description of the downside (e.g., 'wie von einem LKW überfahren') to spike attention and relatability.
Select segments that end with an immediate, easy-to-execute solution statement (e.g., 'Wir können es vermeiden… wenn…') to deliver payoff before drop-off.
Remove segments that are host intros, credentials, or mission statements (speaker bio, applause, 'in den nächsten 18 Minuten', brand positioning) because they delay value delivery.
Remove segments that set up broad context (societal problem framing, 'Massenphänomen') unless they contain a surprising statistic or direct rule.
Remove segments that require multi-step prerequisites or extended frameworks (e.g., explaining 'Tiefschlafverdichtung' at length) when the clip goal is a single actionable takeaway.
Avoid segments where the core point depends on earlier definitions; prefer self-contained micro-lessons that stand alone without context.

timing_patterns.payoff_position: last 8-12 seconds (named problem + how to avoid it)
pacing_rules: Deliver the main rule by ~5-8s (here: 'Vielfachen von 90 Minuten').
Introduce contrast ('but not…') by ~10-18s to prevent monotony and create stakes.
Explain mechanism in one sentence spanning ~10-15s (avoid branching explanations).
Place the strongest emotional/visual phrase around ~25-35s to re-capture attention mid-clip (here: 'LKW überfahren').
End on an actionable conditional ('wenn…') rather than a story beat; keep the last line as a memory cue ('ganz einfach zu merken').
Maintain one idea per clip; if a second idea appears, cut before it starts and use it as the hook for the next clip.

kept_characteristics: Single, compact heuristic that viewers can apply tonight (sleep in 90-minute multiples).
High-clarity structure: analogy → rule → what not to do → why it matters → fix.
Concrete numbers and examples (specific hour options) that reduce ambiguity.
Causal explanation tied to a familiar trigger (alarm clock) rather than abstract biology.
Authority marker via terminology ('Schlaftrunkenheit') without lengthy credentialing.
Relatable pain description that matches common experience (waking groggy despite enough sleep).
removed_characteristics: Speaker introduction, social proof, and event framing (applause, 'internationaler Speaker', '18 Minuten').
Broad motivational framing and mission statements not tied to an immediate action.
Longform educational setup (societal context, extended frameworks like 'Tiefschlafverdichtung' unless distilled).
Audience interaction segments ('Wer hat das schon mal erlebt?') that slow delivery in short-form.
transition_points: Cut starts at the moment a self-contained micro-lesson begins (no preface, no context needed).
Cut preserves the full causal loop (rule + consequence + avoidance) without jumping across unrelated subtopics.

Cut ends right after the actionable resolution cue ('Wir können es vermeiden…') and before any expansion ('Und es ist ganz einfach zu merken,' suggests a natural endpoint or a setup for a follow-up clip).

what_makes_good_cut: Self-contained: viewer understands the problem, rule, and solution without prior segments.
Early value: actionable rule appears within the first 5-8 seconds.
Memorability: includes numbers + a named concept + a vivid metaphor.
Tension/contrast: explicitly states the common mistake ('nicht 7,0 oder 8,0').
Mechanism included: explains why the rule works (alarm interrupts sleep cycle), increasing trust and shares.
Ends with a takeaway phrased as a simple condition (if/then) suitable for captions and on-screen text.
what_makes_bad_cut: Starts with credentials, greetings, or 'today we’ll talk about…' instead of the rule/insight.
Omits either the 'why' or the 'how', leaving only a claim (reduces credibility and retention).
Includes multiple competing tips (sleep cycles + deep sleep + caffeine + screens) in one clip, diluting recall.
Ends mid-explanation or on a setup without delivering the avoidance/solution step.
Uses abstract terms without a concrete example or trigger (e.g., only 'Schlafqualität' talk).
